Award.AwardTitle: Dark Components and Other Cosmological Mysteries Linked Through Extra Dimensions
Award.AbstractNarration:
A remarkably cohesive description of our universe has emerged that confirms
expectations with stunning precision yet simultaneously highlights compelling evidence
for physics beyond our current understanding. Over 95% of the universe is in the
unknown form of dark energy and dark matter. The scale of the dark energy is 15 orders of magnitude lower than the energy scale of dark matter, yet they fill the universe in comparable proportions today. The dark hierarchy is repeated, intriguingly, in a particle physics hierarchy between the electroweak scale and the Planck scale. Attempts to address the particle hierarchy have invoked the existence of extra dimensions bringing a seemingly unrelated list of cosmological mysteries: How are the dimensions stabilized? Why are only three dimensions large? What could have driven anisotropic inflation in the early universe?
The PI proposes that the dark components of the universe are linked to these other
seemingly unrelated cosmological mysteries through one simple facet of the cosmos its
geometry. The dark energy, she suggests, is Casimir energy, a necessary consequence of
quantum mechanics on a finite space. Casimir energy can push the volume of space out
or in, depending on the underlying quantum fields. A superposition of fields allows one
to balance the forces and stabilize the extra dimensions. The dark matter, following
existing suggestions in the literature, could be related to a lightest Kaluza-Klein particle,
another direct consequence of ordinary quantum mechanics on a finite space. The
hierarchy between scales, stabilization of dimensions, as well as early universe
anisotropic inflation can be understood as consequences of these Casimir energies.
The broader impacts of this proposal are that each year one or two undergraduate students from Barnard College, a women's college affiliated with Columbia University, will be involved in this research on dark components and extra dimensions. The students will learn to solve simple systems of differential equations that describe the expansion of a higher-dimensional cosmology. A complementary aspect of her project will involve dissemination of the ideas through public outreach supported by Barnard to girls in NYC high schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Dark Components and Other Cosmological Mysteries Linked

Through Extra Dimensions  –  Janna Levin

A remarkably cohesive description of our universe has been observationally confirmed in a golden era of precision cosmology. Perhaps ironically, the successes of cosmology have simultaneously highlighted compelling evidence for physics beyond our current understanding. Over 95% of the universe is in the unknown form of dark energy and dark matter. The dark components of the universe bring other mysteries. Dark energy is one thousand trillion times less energetic than dark matter, yet they fill the universe in comparable proportions today. This extreme hierarchy between dark components is repeated, intriguingly, in another hierarchy; the strength of gravity is one thousand trillion times weaker than the strength of electromagnetism.

We proposed that the dark components of the universe are consequences of dark dimensions, extra spatial dimensions that are not yet visible to us. Our goal is to link the seemingly unrelated cosmological mysteries through one simple facet of the cosmos – its geometry. We set out to answer questions such as, how is dark energy generated? And dark matter? Why aren’t dark dimensions large? Could these dimensions source an early inflationary episode in the universe? With NSF funding, we addressed these questions in a series of 4 articles.

Intellectual Merit 

Since the very hierarchy of dark components begs explanation, a fusion of solutions that stretches across scales and phenomena is needed. An appealing feature of this proposal is that no particularly exotic phenomena are invoked. All that is needed to link several cosmological mysteries is a geometry beyond simple 3-space. Cosmology requires physics beyond the standard model of particles or gravity or both. The geometry of the universe must be a consequence of that ultimate law of physics. A constraint on the details of global geometry through cosmology would provide a key observation of fundamental physical law.

The dark energy, we suggest, is the irrepressible quantum energy trapped in extra dimensions (technically referred to as Casimir energy). This quantum energy could also preferentially drive 3 dimensions to grow large while the extra dimensions remained small and stable. The dark matter, following existing suggestions in the literature, could be a natural mode of the higher-dimensional space. In this way several cosmological problems are linked.

As additional motivation for considering the large hidden spaces, we argued they provide an attractive candidate to drive an early inflationary epoch. We showed that if the internal dimensions are folded up so that it is energetically expensive to ring out low modes, then the inflation would have cosmologically attractive features (such as a naturally flat potential). Furthermore, the inflaton could double as a dark matter candidate.

This work also inspired us to consider the possibility that large and small extra dimensions co-exist such that electromagnetism is really the consequence of higher-dimensional gravitation, a unifying idea dating back to Kaluza and Klein. This intriguing work is still in progress.

Broader Impacts

Each year undergraduate and graduate students were involved in research to promote integration of scientific research into undergraduate education. Over the 3 summer months funded, half a dozen undergraduates were involved in the PI’s research group. The publications also involved faculty from 4 different departments to develop ideas that drew from mathematics, physics, and astronomy in a genuinely interdisciplinary collaboration.
